physDesc.p: Two pages typewritten in black ink. Mrs. Richard Aldington 44 Mechlenburgh Square London, W.C. England is the typed address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I was very glad indeed to get your letter of November 14th, and to know that you liked the essay on yourself in "Tendencies." I think none of the essays in the book has been so well taken as that one, and I hope that it will stimulate interest in your poetry. A good many people have told me that after reading my book they felt they wanted to go and read the authors themselves, and I only trust that this laudable desire will bear fruit.

Your mother wrote me how much she liked it, and she said something else that gave me even greater pleasure which was that it seemed like you; it almost startled her she felt it was so true a description of your personality. To my mind, nothing could be higher praise than that, except that Richard, who knows you better than anybody, liked the account of your work. I do not suppose that no matter what I said about you as a person I could satisfy him, and quite rightly, but I like to think that it has been my privilege to be the first person to represent you to the world in toto your work and yourself.

Your letter came two or three days ago, and Richardâ€™s of the 18th came just now. I am answering his letter on a separate sheet enclosed. It is really for both of you, of course, but he said so many things I wanted to answer that I thought I would do it this way. What you may say about the Lawrences is perfectly horrible. I feel very sorry for them, and I will send you some money for them in a little while. I think it better to send to you for various reasons, among others, that as they cannot forever live in your room, I shall not know their address until you send it to me. I want to think it over for a few days and see what I can send them, and then I will send you a draft, which you can turn over to them. I am still addressing you at Mechlenburg Square, as I suppose it will be forwarded to you at Litchfield, and I do not know your address there, and Richard says that he will be through with the training school in a couple of weeks and then I suppose you will have to move.
This is not much of a letter. I am just sending it off to acknowledge yours, but it takes a great deal of love from both Mrs. Russell and me.
